div.head: Bifurcations and Feasibility Regions in Differential-Algebraic Systems
div.p: Vaithianathan Venkatasubramanian, Heinz Schattler, and John Zaborszky, Life Fellow, IEEE Abstract-The dynamics of a large class of physical systems such as the general power system can be represented by parameter-dependent differential-algebraic models of the form ci : = f and 0 = g. Typically, such constrained models have singularities. This paper analyzes the generic local bifurcations including those which are directly related to the singularity. The notion of a feasibility region is introduced and analyzed. It consists of all equilibrium states that can be reached quasistatically from the current operating point without loss of l o d stab%@. It is shown that generically loss of stability at the feasibiity boundary is caused by one of three different local bifurcations, namely the well-known saddle-node and Hopf bifurcations and a new bifurcation called the singularity induced bifurcation which is analyzed precisely here for the first time. The latter results when an equilibrium point is at the singular surface. Under certain transversality conditions, the change in the eigenstructure of the system Jacobian at the equilibrium is established and the local dynamical structure of the trajectories near this bifurcation point is analyzed. It is shown generically that the constrained system behavior becomes unpredictable at the singularity induced bifurcation. Global bifurcations do not directly affect stability of equilibria, and as such they cannot occur on the feasibility boundary. Physical phenomena connected with the bifurcations are analyzed with an eye on the limitations of the constrained model. The results presented in this paper are general and applicable to any differential-algebraic equations system, while being motivated here by the large power system.

div.p: In the state-space X x Y , dynamic state variables IC and instantaneous state variables 1~ are distinguished. The dynamics of the states IC are directly defined by (1) while the dynamics of the y variables is such that the system satisfies the constraints (2). The parameters p define a specific system configuration and the operating condition.

As an example, for the power system, typical dynamic state variables are the time-dependent values of generator voltages and rotor phases, and instantaneous variables are bus voltages and other load flow variables. The parameter space P is composed of system parameters (which describe the system topography, i.e., which lines, buses, etc., are energized, and equipment constants such as inductances, transformation ratios, etc.), and operating parameters (such as loads, generation, voltage set-points, etc.). The dynamics of the generators, control devices, and the load dynamics together define the f equations. Typically the constraints g = 0 are defined by the power balance equations of the transmission system. Differential-algebraic systems of the form C have also been used to model the dynamics of many other physical systems The path toward developing an overall theory for large system operation in constrained systems of the form C leads through the study of its state and parameter spaces by identifying suitable regions of operation in these respective spaces. This paper focuses on such a concept by defining a feasible operating region in the parameter space. The feasibility region as defined here has the property that the system operation at the locally stable equilibrium point can be shifted around anywhere within this region by slow parametric variations without losing local stability at the equilibrium. Apart from the local stability requirement, there exist additional criteria for constructing "secure" regions of operation in physical systems. The additional requirements include: 1) inequality constraints on state variables (the viability concept in the power system) and 2) conditions on the ability of the system to survive certain large disturbances (the notion of transient stability in the power system) [6]. Based on these concepts, a theorybase for secure operating regions has been studied in [6]- [8] for the large system C. This paper analyzes the feasibility regions (related to local stability) in detail as a first step toward developing suitable operating regions in a physical system.

The bifurcation theory provides a natural platform for studying the parameter space phenomena by establishing the dynamic mechanisms that effect changes in the system structure upon parameter variations. When the system parameters are varied, the dynamics of the system C changes continuously; however, topologically the structure remains unchanged under small (parametric) perturbations provided the system is structurally stable ([91, [lo]) at the given parameter value. Structurally unstable points then identify the parameter values where the structure or the type of the system undergoes changes. This concept of structural stability naturally leads to the notion of typal regions in the parameter space which can be defined as the connected components of structurally stable parameter values within the parameter space. It follows that the topology of the state space or of the phase portrait remains uniform within a typal region; hence, the same type of system operation prevails within any typal region. Therefore the parameter space is composed of typal regions (regions of structural stability) bounded by bifurcation surfaces (structurally unstable points).

An understanding of all the typal regions and their boundaries could therefore provide us with a comprehensive overview of the system operation clearly outlining the evolution of all significant dynamic phenomena. For smallscale systems, such a characterization of typal regions is indeed possible, and an example can be seen in (1 11 and [ 121 for a two-dimensional (n = 2) rudimentary power system model. At the present time, however, such a complete overview of the parameter space seems to be impossible even theoretically for large nonlinear systems. This is because the boundary of the typal regions consists of local and global bifurcations. Specifically the global bifurcations in general can themselves be dense in open sets of the parameter space (see [9], complex behavior), which then renders the problem extremely difficult to analyze even for system dimension three (n = 3), let alone the large system. For these reasons and as a first step, we restrict the analysis in this paper to the study of a simpler concept in the parameter space called the notion of feasibility regions.

Feasibility regions are defined as the union of certain typal regions with the property that the operating point is guaranteed to be locally stable under any quasistatic parameter variation within the feasibility region. Therefore within a feasibility region, as the parameters are varied, there may exist several structurally different system types; however, the local stability at the current operating point remains unaffected by crossing these interior typal boundaries. An example is a distant saddle point changing to say a source which is a local bifurcation, hence forming a typal boundary; however, this bifurcation is practically uninteresting and is ignored within the feasibility region. Thus the authors' analysis reveals a two-level cellular structure of the parameter space as shown in Table I (a similar structure emerges for the state space, but the latter will not be discussed here

In Section I1 of this paper, the notion of feasibility regions is developed precisely, and we show that the feasibility boundary (the boundary of the feasibility region) has an inherently simple algebraic structure and hence can be easily computed even in very large scale systems. In Section 111, it is proved that generically the feasibility boundary for the DAE system C consists of the set of closures of three bifurcation surfaces, namely the well-known saddle-node and Hopf bifurcations and a new bifurcation called the singularity induced bifurcation [6].

Systems of the form C typically have singular points where the implicit function theorem for solving the constraints g = 0 is not applicable. When the constraints (2) are absent [lo]). For constrained models C, however, the feasibility boundary typically also contains another bifurcation segment named (by us) the singularity induced bifurcation which occurs when the system equilibrium is at the singularity. When this happens, it has been observed that some of the system eigenvalues may become unbounded ([11]-[ 171). This scenario is rigorously analyzed in [ 113 and [12] for a specific power system model with n = 2 and m = 1. For the general large system, under certain transversality conditions, we have proved [6] that the eigenstructure of the system Jacobian changes at this bifurcation point with one eigenvalue diverging to infinity. Here the analysis is extended to explore the geometry of the system trajectories near all three bifurcation boundaries. For the saddle-node bifurcation boundary, such an analysis was presented in [18] for certain unconstrained power system models.

The roles of Hopf [19] and saddle-node bifurcations [13] in understanding specific power system phenomena have been recognized recently. Hopf bifurcations have been observed in power system models connected with unstable limit cycles ([ll], [12], [20]- [22]). It has been observed that system transients near Hopf bifurcation points are oscillatory ([ 111, [12], [22]); this will also be demonstrated in this paper for the large system using the center manifold theory. Currently, computational methods are being developed for locating the saddle-node and Hopf bifurcations in the parameter space

For the singularity induced bifurcation, it will be shown that generically even when the equilibrium is at the singularity, there exists an (n -1)-dimensional invariant manifold W r e g that passes through the singularity such that the dynamics E restricted to the invariant manifold is smooth. Moreover, this invariant manifold is locally "attracting" on one side of the singular surface and "repelling" on the other side, thereby providing a "conduit" for the trajectories from one side of the singular surface to cross over to the other side at finite speed, possibly either 1) diverging toward a new steady-state condition or 2) ending at the singular surface. The constrained model C itself does not provide sufficient information to distinguish between the two different types of behaviors near the singularity. In this sense, the singularity induced bifurcation denotes a true barrier to predictable behavior with the model C from a mathematical as well as an engineering viewpoint. Moreover, the loss of reliable system prediction using C at this bifurcation follows for any constrained model of the form C under certain generic transversality assumptions and is not related to specific modeling assumptions like the limitations of the quasistationary assumption in phasor power system models. More details will be given in Section V.

Global bifurcations have also been studied with much interest recently since some of these bifurcations may indicate chaotic system behavior ([ll], [12], [217, [22], [281- [311). For the reasons mentioned above, global bifurcations are not relevant to the study of the feasibility region and therefore this paper only deals with the generic local bifurcations for the large system E.

The organization of the paper is as follows. The definition and properties of the feasibility region are given in Section 11, and the principal local bifurcation structure of the feasibility boundary is analyzed in Section 111. The singularity induced bifurcation is established in detail in Section J Y .

Discussions on the physical implications of all the three generic bifurcations, namely the saddle-node, Hopf, and the singularity induced bifurcations, follow in Section V with special emphasis on the constrained nature (2) of the model E; some illustrative simulations are given in Section VI. Even though the illustrations are given for the power system, the results as stated are applicable to any system of the form E.

div.p: A notion of feasibility regions is introduced in this section by identifying the set of all equilibrium points which can be reached quasistatically (or in a stationary sense) from a given stable equilibrium point by continuous parameter variations without loss of stability. div.head: Iv. ANALYSIS OF THE SINGULARITY INDUCED BIFURCATION
div.p: When the steady-state solution or an equilibrium point in EQ approaches the singularity S , it has been observed that some eigenvalues of the system Jacobian at the equilibrium point may become unbounded ([ 1114 171). In [ 111 and [ 121, it was shown that for a two-dimensional system, this case generally is "equivalent" to a transcritical bifurcation ("exchange of stability" bifurcation [9]). In the large system, however, it is no longer related to the transcritical bifurcation. In this section, we analyze this scenario for the general system (1) and (2), when the equilibrium approaches the singularity. As the change in the structure is due to the presence of the singular surface, we call this bifurcation a singularity induced bifurcation. Note that when the equilibrium is at the singularity, the
div.formula: Jacobian J := D, f -D, f (D,g)-'D,g is not well defined because D,g is singular.
div.p: Intuitively it is clear that the Jacobian J might have some unbounded eigenvalues near the bifurcation point, because J involves the inversion of a singular matrix D,g. From an engineering point of view, the critical questions then are: 1) Does the equilibrium "survive" the bifurcation (unlike in the case of the saddle-node bifurcation)? and 2) Do the real parts of the (unbounded) eigenvalues at the equilibrium change sign? A change in the sign of the real parts of the eigenvalues is significant because then the stability status of the equilibrium would undergo a change at the bifurcation point. The singularity induced bifurcation theorem to be presented in this section proves that generically the equilibrium exists near the bifurcation and the stability status of the equilibrium undergoes a change with exactly one eigenvalue becoming unbounded at the bifurcation point. Hence this bifurcation corresponds to a loss of stable operation at the current stable equilibrium point as defined above.

For the large power system, we need to be careful in interpreting the results near the singularity because the validity of the phasor dynamic model C hinges on the quasistationary assumption, namely that the speeds of the states II: and 1~ are slow as compared to the carrier signal (of frequency 60 Hz in the US). It can be shown that the error caused by the quasistationary approximation is zero at the equilibrium since the speeds are zero there but the error grows in magnitude away from the equilibrium. Typically the quasistationary assumption serves as an excellent approximation everywhere within the state space except near the singular segments where the error becomes unbounded [38].

Specifically local arguments such as stability of the equilibrium point based on the model C are applicable near an equilibrium as long as the equilibrium is away from the singularity. Therefore, the local stability results of the mathematical model C are physically valid locally near the equilibrium everywhere, except possibly at the bifurcation point itself when the equilibrium is at the singularity. Of course, the size of the neighborhood in which these results are applicable may and typically will shrink to zero as the singularity induced bifurcation point is reached. Here we note that since the equilibrium becomes unstable after the bifurcation and is away from the singularity in the model C as will be proved in the theorem, the equilibrium in the actual system does indeed become locally unstable upon crossing the singularity induced bifurcation boundary. Irrespective of the modeling issues discussed above, physical system operation at the current operating state ends before the singularity induced bifurcation boundary. In other words, the singularity induced bifurcation segment of the feasibility boundary corresponds to a true physical boundary (quite predictable) for stable system operation at the current operating point. Caution should be exercised in analyzing the exact nature of the transients diverging from the unstable equilibrium because of the failing quasistationarity near the singular surface. A detailed analysis of the transients follows in Sections IV-E and V-A.

The three bifurcation segments of the feasibility boundary discussed in this paper are physical boundaries in the parameter space where stable system operation ends as the parameter crosses the boundary segment. There is a need for understanding how the instability develops in the state space around the operating point when such boundaries are encountered in real system operation. Such an understanding will help us in developing some intuition on the type of instability which the system may face at a particular feasibility boundary segment and for on-line identification of imminent trouble in real system operation so that suitable countermeasures can be initiated. Hence the discussion in this section is aimed at an engineering analysis of the bifurcations (unlike the rigorous mathematical treatment in the previous sections) for developing the qualitative evolution of the state space dynamics near the feasibility boundary segments. The analysis of the saddle-node bifurcation segments was developed in [18] motivated by the voltage collapse phenomena in a large (unconstrained) power system model based on certain assumptions on the parameter variation. Here we will proceed to consider all the three boundary segments in sequence for the constrained system E. The variation of a single p a m e t e r p will be considered to simplify the presentation, but the results naturally extend to the full set of parameters p with the transversality assumptions as stated in Section m.

For the saddle-node and Hopf feasibility boundary segments, namely for Bsp,~ n d F and BH n d F , the structural changes which lead to the bifurcation phenomena (in other words the instability mechanisms) are well understood in nonlinear dynamics [9] and are summarized in Fig. 5 (saddle-node bifurcation) and Figs. 6 and 7 (Hopf bifurcations), respectively. div.p: The structure of the parameter spaces are illustrated in Fig. 9 at the generator and the SVC control at the load bus. Here the parameter P is the active power load and K is the control gain. These are the two parameters to which the system is most sensitive. Fig. 9(a) and (b) cover an active window of the P -K cross-section. It can be shown [12] that this rudimentary system has at most two equilibria, say Xh and xt, corresponding to highand low-load bus voltages. So there are two sets of local bifurcations connected, respectively, with the high Xh and low xe voltage equilibria along with the saddle-node bifurcation where these two equilibria meet and annihilate each other. Therefore, for either equilibrium point, feasibility ends at the saddle-node bifurcation, unless it ended elsewhere before.

Fig. 9(a) and (b) outline all the bifurcations (local and global) for the rudimentary system within the windows of the respective plots. These then are by definition the typal boundaries, i.e., loci where state-space topology changes. Feasibility, however, is defined over the region where a specific stable equilibrium point has persistent local stability. Hence, when identifying the feasibility boundary and region for the high equilibrium Xh, only bifurcation surfaces connected with the stable high equilibrium x h are relevant as shown by heavy lines in Fig. 9 Moreover, for a general nonlinear system, there may exist many feasibility regions connected with different stable equilibria. For the rudimentary system, indeed there exist two feasibility regions related to the two equilibria Xh (discussed above) and xe. The feasibility boundaries for these two regions, that is, for the high voltage x h and the low voltage xe equilibria will be different and are displayed in Fig. 1O(a) and (b) for the excitation control and SVC control cases, respectively. In Fig. lO(a), the feasibility region is larger for the lower equilibrium xe compared to that of x h at heavy loads (above D) and vice versa. In Fig. 10(b), however, the feasibility region for the high voltage equilibrium x h is always larger compared to that of the low voltage equilibrium Xe. Interestingly, these two types of control for this example result in diagrams which are both quite different in detail yet rather similar in their overall structure. Moreover, caution is in order while assessing the practical validity of the feasibility region related to xt for this rudimentary system because of other related issues such as viability concerns (possibly resulting in too high line currents) and stability requirements in the sense of overall system dynamics which are not considered in this paper.

Details of these occurrences are available in [12]. div.head: VII. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: The paper analyzes the local dynamical behavior of large differential-algebraic systems near the three generic local bifurcation segments which are the principal constituents of the feasibility boundaries, namely the saddle-node, Hopf, and the singularity induced bifurcations. Transients near the saddle-node bifurcation segments diverge monotonously while the transients near the Hopf bifurcation boundaries diverge away from the unstable equilibrium in an oscillatory fashion. Transient behavior of the constrained system C cannot be predicted near the singularity induced bifurcation segments. Analytically it is shown that the system may display smooth behavior near the singularity induced bifurcation, yet the actual system behavior will be unpredictable near this bifurcation for the DAE model C . More detailed system models are necessary for further analysis. Bifurcation phenomena connected with global bifurcations and other interior feasibility boundary segments need more investigation for large systems.
